The sutra says: I vow that in the future, for innumerable eons, I will always see the great golden drum in my dreams, and hear the sound of repentance and confession, praising the Buddha's virtues as likened to a lotus flower.

At night I always hear the wonderful drum sound in my dreams, and during the day I repent accordingly.
I will perfect the practice of the six pÄramitÄs, deliver sentient beings from the sea of suffering, and then attain supreme enlightenment.

If there are sentient beings without protection, wandering in the long night and suffering various hardships, I will be their refuge in the future, enabling them to attain peace and joy.

May the sufferings of the three realms be eliminated, and may all attain the blissful abode according to their wishes. In future lives, cultivating bodhi, may they all be like the Buddhas of the past.

May the light of my body be equal to that of all Buddhas, and may my blessings, virtues, and wisdom be the same. In all worlds, may I alone be honored, with power and freedom unmatched.

May I transcend the ocean of suffering with outflows, and may I always roam in the ocean of unconditioned bliss. May the ocean of blessings in the present always be full, and may the ocean of wisdom in the future be perfectly complete.

I vow that my buddha land will transcend the three realms, with supreme merits and virtues immeasurable, and all those with karmic affinity will be reborn there together, all attaining pure wisdom swiftly.
Commentary:
The golden drum proclaims the sound of repentance, which should be placed later, because the vow is made after presenting the golden drum. It is explained here for convenience.
The specific manifestations are eight:
One verse is the first vow, dreaming.
The second is one verse vowing to praise the Buddha's virtues, likened to an udumbara flower.
The third is half a verse vowing to practice repentance.
The fourth is one verse vowing to cultivate various good deeds, with four parts:
One practices the six pÄramitÄs, two saves sentient beings, three vows to become a buddha, and four vows to purify the buddha land.
The fifth is one verse vowing to attain the prediction.
The sixth is one verse vowing for the children to be the same.

The next two verses are vows for benefiting others in the future. In benefiting others, the first verse and a half causes them to attain worldly happiness, and the last half verse causes them to attain supramundane happiness, according to the superior [benefit] causing them to attain great fruition;

Or it may be that the last half verse below sentient beings in the three existences causes them to attain the three vehicles, saying according to their minds, and later causes them to turn their minds towards the great [vehicle].
The next six verses are vows for attaining benefits for oneself. There are six in attaining benefits for oneself:

The first verse is a vow to repent and eliminate hindrances to attain nirvana. The sea of suffering is the hindrance of retribution, karma is the hindrance of karma, and afflictions are the hindrance of delusion;
The next verse is a vow to attain the dharma body and wisdom to accomplish great enlightenment, to attain the reward body;
The next verse is a vow to attain the light of the body and wisdom to illuminate others, to manifest the transformation body;
The next verse is a vow for the light of the body and wisdom to be equal to all buddhas;

The next verse is a vow to transcend the sea of suffering and perfect happiness. There are two in this, half a verse on leaving suffering and attaining happiness, and half a verse on the perfection of blessings and the fulfillment of wisdom.
The perfection of blessings is the practice of causes, and the fulfillment of wisdom is the fruition.

Sublime Banner, you should know, King Golden Dragon Lord, once made such a vow, he is none other than your body.
At that time there were two sons, Golden Dragon and Golden Light, they are none other than Silver Appearance and Silver Light, who will receive my prediction.
